On second thought, if I'm evolving a 5x5 board evaluator and treat it as i=
f it is 7x7, then band pruning will remove the excess edge nodes without au=
tomatically clobbering the 5x5 edge nodes.  I wonder how effective that wou=
ld be.

Tony

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "wilsontg80" <wilsontg@...> wrot=
e:
>
> 
> What I mean is the band pruning seems too restrictive.  Suppose a=
 CPPN substrate is being pruned for a Go game board evaluator.  If ideally =
the weights along the board edge should be expressed they will be removed b=
y band pruning. Am I missing something?
> 
> Tony 
>  
> --- In neat@yahoog=
roups.com, "Ken" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > 
> > 
> > Hi Tony, I believe th=
e issue there is with the definition of a "band":
> > 
> > "points that are=
 enclosed by at least two neighbors on opposite sides (e.g. left and right)=
 with di=0Bfferent CPPN activation levels"
> > 
> > Note that the points in=
 the outer black region do not have _two_ neighbors of different level on o=
pposite sides, so I believe that is the reason they are pruned away.  Howev=
er, it's possible that I'm misunderstanding the question, in which case ple=
ase let me know.
> > 
> > Regarding the quote that says, "the CPPN speaks a=
 language through its pattern," this idea conveys that of course there is m=
ore than one way to interpret the patterns output by CPPNs for this purpose=
, and any such method of interpretation is a kind of language.  In other wo=
rds, there might be other perfectly legitimate ways of deciding which conne=
ctions to express from an infinite-resolution pattern that are different fr=
om the method in the paper (i.e. those would be different "languages" for t=
he CPPN to express what it wants).  
> > 
> > However, the "language" sugge=
sted in the paper is nice in the sense that it allows the CPPN to express o=
ne type of connection without being forced to express another at the same t=
ime - that's what the band pruning achieves.  Otherwise you'd get points ch=
osen on both sides of a sharp border, forcing connections often to be chose=
n in pairs (which seems an undesirable tendency).
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > 
> =
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "wilsontg80" <wilsontg@> wrote:
> > >
> > > =
I am puzzled by the result of band pruning in Figure 3: Example point selec=
tion in two dimensions, from Evolving the Placement and Density of Neurons =
in the HyperNEAT Substrate.  It seems like the information inherent in the =
image should include points along the black-white edge of the outer black r=
egion, but band pruning removes them all.  The figure explains "In effect, =
the CPPN speaks a language through its pattern that denotes exactly which w=
eights within the hypercube should be expressed."  I am curious why "langua=
ge" is used here.  
> > > 
> > > My goal is to add iterated ES-HyperNEAT to=
 the C++ version at https://github.com/MisterTea/HyperNEAT.  I am presently=
 a hobbyist (my profession is embedded software engineering) but considerin=
g to someday pursue a PhD involving HyperNEAT, etc.
> > > 
> > > Thanks,
> =
> > Tony Wilson
> > >
> >
>
